description: Training scenarios for ISORA ransomware simulation

scenarios.name: Corporate Workstation Ransomware
scenarios.description: A typical ransomware incident on a corporate workstation - ideal for beginners
scenarios.background: You are the on-call security analyst at a mid-sized company. At 14:30, you receive a call from an employee in the Finance department reporting strange behavior on their workstation. The employee sounds concerned but the situation appears contained to a single system.
scenarios.initial_situation:
The employee reports:
- A strange text file appeared on their desktop
- Some of their files have unusual extensions
- The computer seems slower than usual
- They clicked on an email attachment about an invoice earlier today

The workstation (WS-FIN-042) is still powered on and connected to the network.
objectives: Preserve volatile evidence (memory) before taking containment actions
Identify the ransomware variant based on available indicators
Safely contain the affected system without destroying evidence
Document all findings and actions taken
expected_findings: Ransom note with bitcoin address and instructions
Files with .encrypted_sim extension in Documents folder
Email attachment as likely infection vector
hints: Check the desktop for any new text files
Look for files with unusual extensions
Memory capture should be done BEFORE network isolation
Document the contents of the ransom note carefully
Check the user's email and recent downloads

scenarios.name: Ransomware with Lateral Movement
scenarios.description: A more complex scenario involving multiple systems and lateral movement
scenarios.background: What started as a single workstation incident has escalated. Multiple departments are now reporting similar issues. The IT team is overwhelmed and needs your expertise to coordinate the response. This appears to be a coordinated attack that has spread beyond the initial infection point.
scenarios.initial_situation:
Current reports:
- Finance department: 2 workstations affected (WS-FIN-042, WS-FIN-018)
- HR department: 1 workstation affected (WS-HR-007)
- IT admin workstation showing suspicious authentication events
- File server alerts from antivirus (potentially false positive)

The incidents occurred within a 30-minute window, suggesting automated propagation.
objectives: Identify all affected systems through systematic analysis
Determine the lateral movement method used by the attacker
Coordinate containment actions across multiple systems
Preserve evidence from multiple sources without cross-contamination
expected_findings: Multiple systems with identical ransomware indicators
Suspicious authentication events from service account
Evidence of SMB lateral movement between systems
hints: Check authentication logs for unusual patterns across all DCs
Look for evidence of PsExec or similar remote execution tools
Service accounts are often targeted for lateral movement
Create a timeline to understand the spread pattern
Check for scheduled tasks on affected systems

scenarios.name: Ransomware with Data Exfiltration
scenarios.description: Advanced scenario combining ransomware with data theft indicators
scenarios.background: The attackers appear to have been in the environment for some time before deploying ransomware. There are indicators that sensitive data may have been exfiltrated before the encryption began. This is a double-extortion scenario where the attackers may threaten to publish stolen data.
scenarios.initial_situation:
Security team has identified:
- Ransomware deployed across multiple systems
- Large outbound data transfers to unknown IPs in the past week
- Evidence of archive files created before ransomware deployment
- Attackers have left a note threatening to publish data

Executive leadership is requesting immediate status updates.
objectives: Assess the scope of potential data exfiltration
Identify what data may have been accessed or stolen
Coordinate with legal and compliance teams
Preserve evidence for potential law enforcement involvement
expected_findings: Evidence of data staging and compression
Access logs showing sensitive file access
hints: Check for large archive files created recently
Review firewall logs for unusual outbound traffic
Look for evidence of staging directories
Review file server access logs for sensitive areas
Consider the legal implications of data breach
